text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

-I wake up the 12th-- a call
from my supervisor saying, on

the 13th, I'm supposed to report
to 1 Broadway to do
cleanup work.

-On September 11, Alex Sanchez,
a 34-year-old

maintenance worker, ran from the
dust cloud with thousands
of fellow downtown workers.

On September 12, he became part
of a special group of

laborers assigned to clean
office buildings affected by
the collapse of the towers.

-My job was cleaning the air
ducts and AC units, and doing

the floors, the cubicles,
offices.
We did everything.

We worked extremely hard,
12-hour days, seven days a

week, for myself, for
seven months.

-Only yards away from where the
Twin Towers once stood,

the World Financial Center today
shows no trace of the

destruction cleanup workers like
Alex encountered in the
days after 9/11.
-Glass shattered all over.
There was blood on the walls.

But what really struck me was
the amount of dust. The air
was very thick, tons of smoke.

Watery eyes, sore throat,
immediately the first day.

-To protect himself from the
conditions, Alex covered his
face with a bandanna.
-No protection whatsoever.

No respirators, nothing
like that.

People started leaving
[UNINTELLIGIBLE]

because there were times that we
didn't even have the white
paper masks.

And some of the workers said,
we're not going to work
without the paper masks.

And the supervisors said OK,
we're going to pay you guys

double if you stay, to
those people who
didn't have the masks.

I never really thought about
it back then, but thinking

about it today, it really makes
a whole lot of sense,

why they were paying double
for the people to stay.

They needed the workers, but
they didn't want to give the
money for the protection.

-Alex Sanchez's five-year-old
son watches his father

struggle daily with the
effects of 9/11.

-Every day, he asks me, Daddy,
how are you doing today?
Are you sick today?

Are you going to go to
the doctor today?

I've been robbed of life's
most precious moments.
I can't carry my son.

I can't toss a baseball
with him.

I suffer from occupational
asthma, upper airway disease

in the lungs, chronic lung
disease, bronchitis,

musculoskeletal syndrome,
gastrointestinal reflux.

I had a tuberculosis skin test
done, and I tested positive.

I have also developed nodules
in my lungs, which is the
first sign of cancer.

-Unable to work, Alex lives on
$200 a week from a partial

workers' compensation
settlement.
-Throw it to daddy.

There's days that I just want
to quit and just lay there.
But I can't.

I have this little person that
really, really needs me.

And that's where my strength
comes from.

I don't know how long I'm
going to be here for.

I just have to do my best, and
my best should be enough.

Good boy Both feet,
there you go.
